sentence-detokenized: The EU rejects Germany's call for a boycott of British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRUSSELS 1996-08-22

The European Commission said on Thursday it does not agree with Germany's advice to consumers to avoid British sheepmeat until scientists establish whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

Germany's representative on the European Union's veterinary committee, Werner Zwingmann, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy lamb from countries other than Britain until scientific advice is clearer.
"We do not support any such recommendation because we see no basis for it," Commission Secretary-General Nikolaus van der Pas told a press conference.
He said that further scientific studies are needed and if measures are found to be necessary, the European Union should take them.

He said EU Agriculture Commissioner Franz Fischler's proposal last month to ban the use of sheep brains, spleens and spinal cords in the food chain for humans and animals was a very concrete and precautionary measure to protect human health.
Fischler proposed EU-wide measures following reports from the UK and France that sheep could be suffering from bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) - mad cow disease - in laboratory conditions.

However, Fischler agreed to reconsider his proposal after the EU's Standing Veterinary Committee, which is made up of national animal health officials, questioned whether such measures were justified as there was only a small risk to human health.
Spain's Agriculture Minister Loyola de Palacio accused Fischler of causing unwarranted alarm at an earlier meeting of EU agriculture ministers through "dangerous generalisations".
Only France and the UK supported Fischler's proposal.
The EU's scientific veterinary and multidisciplinary committees are due to re-examine the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
It has long been known that sheep can contract scrapie, a brain-damaging disease similar to BSE, which is thought to have been passed on to cattle through feed containing animal waste.

British farmers denied on Thursday that their lamb posed a risk to human health, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could affect consumers across Europe.
"We have to be extremely careful about how other countries follow Germany's lead," John Lloyd Jones, chairman of the National Farmers Union (NFU) in Wales, told BBC radio.

Bonn has led efforts to protect public health after consumer confidence plummeted in March following a British report that people may have contracted a condition similar to mad cow disease after eating contaminated beef.
Germany imported 47 600 sheep from the UK last year, almost half of total imports.
It imported 4,275 tonnes of British sheepmeat, which represents about 10 percent of total imports.
A rare draft of a Hendrix song sells for almost $17 000.
A rare early handwritten draft of one of US guitar legend Jimi Hendrix's songs sold for nearly $17 000 at an auction of the musician's favourite possessions last Thursday.
A Florida restaurant paid £10 925 ($16 935) for the song "Ain't no telling", which Hendrix wrote on stationery in a London hotel in late 1966.
At the end of a concert in Nottingham, England, in January 1967, he threw a piece of paper into the audience, where a fan found it.
Buyers also bought 16 other items auctioned off by Hendrix's ex-girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with Hendrix from 1966 to 1969.
Among them was a black lacquer and mother-of-pearl inlay box used by Hendrix to store his drugs, bought by an anonymous Australian buyer for £5060 ($7,845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970 at the age of 27.
China says Taiwan is spoiling the negotiating atmosphere.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China on Thursday accused Taiwan Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Ukraine this week, which irritated Beijing, of spoiling the atmosphere for continued talks across the Taiwan Strait.

Foreign ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters just hours after Chinese state media reported that the time was right to start political talks with Taiwan: "Taiwanese authorities have disrupted the atmosphere necessary for the opening of talks."
State media quoted top Chinese negotiator Tang Shubei, who is holding talks with Taipei, as telling a Taiwan visiting group on Wednesday that it was time for the rivals to hold political talks.
"Now is the time for both sides to start political talks....
which is the cessation of hostilities," Tang was quoted as saying by the foreign edition of People's Daily on Thursday.

The Foreign Ministry's Shen said in an interview with Reuters television that he had read reports of Tang's comments but gave no details on why the negotiator considered the timing right for talks with Taiwan, which Beijing considers a renegade province.
China, which has long opposed any attempt by Taipei to gain greater international recognition, was infuriated by Taiwanese Vice President Lien's visit to Ukraine this week.
China says the time is right for Taiwan talks.
BEIJING 1996-08-22
China has said it is time for political talks with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps to achieve this.

Consultations should be held to determine the timing and format of the talks, the official Xinhua news agency quoted Tang Shubei, vice-chairman of the Taiwan Association for Cross-Straits Relations, as saying late on Wednesday.
German car registrations in July grew by 14.2 percentage points year-on-year.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
First-time registrations of German motor vehicles increased by 14.2 percent in July this year compared with July last year, the German Federal Motor Vehicle Office said on Thursday.
According to the Agency, 356 725 new passenger cars were registered in July 1996 - 304 850 passenger cars and 15 613 lorries.
This is 13.6 percent less for passenger cars and 2.2 percent less for trucks than in July 1995.
Registrations of motorcycles increased by 32.7 per cent during this period.
The increase was partly due to Germans buying more and more German cars abroad, while manufacturers reported that domestic demand was weak, the federal agency said.
Almost all German carmakers showed an increase in registrations during the period.
Volkswagen AG won 77 719 registrations, just over a quarter of the total.
Opel AG, together with General Motors, came second with 49 269 registrations, representing 16.4 percent of the total.
Ford was third with 35 563 registrations, or 11.7%.
Only Seat and Porsche registered fewer cars in July 1996 than the previous July.
Seat registered 3,420 vehicles, compared to 5,522 registrations in July a year earlier.
Porsche registrations fell from 643 to 554.
GREEK SOCIALISTS GIVE GREEN LIGHT TO ELECTIONS.
The leadership of the Greek Socialist Party gave the green light to Prime Minister Costas Simitis to call early elections, General Secretary Costas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis will make the formal announcement after a cabinet meeting later on Thursday, Skandalidis said.

Israel is reducing fears of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUUSALEMMA 1996-08-22
Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said on Thursday that current tensions between the two countries appeared to be in the eye of a storm.
Itamar Rabinovich, who as Israel's ambassador in Washington held fruitless talks with Syria, told Israel Radio that Damascus seems to want to talk rather than fight.
"It seems to me that the {(1)[MISC] Syria priority} is still the negotiations.
The Syrians are confused, they're certainly tense, but the general assessment here in Washington is that it's essentially a storm in a tea cup," he said.
Rabinovich's term as ambassador is coming to an end.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, a former Israeli envoy to Egypt and politician from the right-wing Likud party.
On Wednesday, Israel sent a message to Syria via Washington, saying it was committed to peace and willing to start negotiations without preconditions.
But he accused Damascus of creating what he called a dangerous climate.
Syria on Wednesday accused Israel of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli television reported that Damascus had recently test-fired a missile.
He said his arms purchases were for defence purposes.
"The message we sent to (Syrian President Hafez al-) Assad is that Israel is ready to start peace talks at any time and without preconditions," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy told Israel Radio.
After Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took office in June and pledged to preserve the Golan Heights, which Israel captured from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli-Syrian peace talks have been deadlocked over the Golan since 1991, despite the previous government's willingness to make concessions on the Golan.
Peace talks between the two sides were last held in February.
"The voices coming from Damascus are bad, not good.
Media...
is full of expressions and statements that must be alarming...
this artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its prisoners," said Levy.
"We expect Syria, if it has a face towards peace, to respond to Israel's message to enter into peace negotiations, because that is our goal," he said. "
We don't want war, God forbid.
Wars benefit no one. "
Israel's Channel Two said Damascus had sent a "reassuring signal" to Israel.
He did not provide the source of the report.
Spokesmen for Netanyahu and Levy said they could not confirm this.
Television also said that Netanyahu has sent messages to pacify Syria through Cairo, the United States and Moscow.
Polish diplomat denies nurses in distress in Libya.
A Polish diplomat on Thursday denied a report in a Polish tabloid this week that Libya is refusing exit visas to 100 Polish nurses trying to return home after working in the North African country.
"This is not true.

To date, we are not aware of any nurses being detained or detained in Libya against their will, and we have not received any complaints," Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, a representative of the Polish Embassy in Tripoli, told Reuters by telephone.

Poland's labour ministry announced this week that it would send an investigation team to Libya, but Awdankiewicz said the investigation was prompted by some nurses complaining about their working conditions, such as non-payment of wages.
He said an estimated 800 Polish nurses are working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iran-based Iranian refugee group pledged on Thursday to extend support to Iran's Kurdish rebels after Iranian forces attacked them deep inside Iraq last month.

According to a statement by Mujahideen Khalq, its leader Massoud Rajavi met Hassan Rastegar, Secretary General of the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran (KDPI), in Baghdad on Wednesday and expressed support for the Iranian Kurdish rebels.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian Resistance will continue to stand side by side with its Kurdish compatriots and the resistance movement in Iranian Kurdistan," it said.
A spokesman for the group said the meeting "signals a new level of cooperation between Mujahideen Khalq and the Iranian Kurdish opposition".
In July, Iran heavily bombed targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of KDPI guerrillas based in Iraqi Kurdish areas outside Baghdad's government control.
The Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering Iran are under the control of the guerrillas of the Iraqi Kurdistan Kurdistan Patriotic Union (PUK).
The PUK and the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iraq (KDP), the two main Iraqi Kurdish factions, have held control of northern Iraq since the expulsion of Iraqi forces from Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Clashes between the two sides erupted over the weekend in the most serious clashes since the US-backed ceasefire last year.
Mujahideen Khalq said that Iranian forces have also shelled KDP positions in the Qasr region of Suleimaniya province, near the Iranian border, over the past two days.
He said about 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or wounded in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey are conducting air strikes and ground attacks against targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of their Kurdish rebels.
The US-led air force in southern Turkey protects Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by Baghdad forces.
The Saudi rial is stable in the calm summer trade.
Saudi Arabia's spot rial exchange rate against the dollar and rial interbank deposit rates were mostly stable this week during quiet summer trade, dealers in the kingdom said.
"The Saudi rial rates have not changed.
The market was very quiet because of the summer holidays," said one dealer.
The local rial was pegged at 3.7504 / 06 against the dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were 5-1/2, 3/8 percent, three-month deposits were 5-5/8, 1/2 percent, and six-month deposits were 5-3/4, 5/8 percent.
One-year funds were at six, 5-7/8 percent.
Israel approves Arafat's escape to the West Bank.
JERUUSALEMMA 1996-08-22
Israel on Thursday gave Palestinian President Yasser Arafat permission to fly over its territory to the West Bank, ending a brief Israeli-PLO crisis, an Arafat adviser said.
"The problem has been solved.
The president's plane has been cleared to pass through Israeli airspace, but the president is not expected to travel to the West Bank until Monday," Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat was due to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in West Bank Ramallah on Thursday, but the meeting was changed to Gaza after Israel refused to grant the Palestinian leader permission to fly helicopters.
Palestinian officials accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah meeting by keeping Arafat down.
Arafat then cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials on civilian issues at the Allenby Bridge between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said Arafat decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday, after Israel lifted the ban, because he had a tight schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat meets Peres in Gaza after the flight ban.
JERUUSALEMMA 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat meets Shimon Peres in Gaza on Thursday after Palestinians reported that Israel's right-wing government banned the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank to hold talks with the former prime minister.

Japan's Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said at a press conference on Wednesday that in his view the interest rate policy of the Bank of Japan (BOJ), which is geared towards economic growth, has not changed since the publication of the central bank's Tankan survey.
